films.title: La Haine
films.tagline: How far you fall doesn't matter, it's how you land…
films.description: After a chaotic night of rioting in a marginal suburb of Paris, three young friends, Vinz, Hubert and Saïd, wander around unoccupied waiting for news about the state of health of a mutual friend who has been seriously injured when confronting the police.

films.title: The Young Girls of Rochefort
films.tagline: …They're singing and dancing in the streets.
films.description: Delphine and Solange are two sisters living in Rochefort. Delphine is a dancing teacher and Solange composes and teaches the piano. Maxence is a poet and a painter. He is doing his military service. Simon owns a music shop, he left Paris one month ago to come back where he fell in love 10 years ago. They are looking for love, looking for each other, without being aware that their ideal partner is very close...

films.title: Amélie
films.description: At a tiny Parisian café, the adorable yet painfully shy Amélie accidentally discovers a gift for helping others. Soon Amélie is spending her days as a matchmaker, guardian angel, and all-around do-gooder. But when she bumps into a handsome stranger, will she find the courage to become the star of her very own love story?

films.title: Petite Maman
films.tagline: Experience a fairytale of wonder and innocence.
films.description: After the death of her beloved grandmother, eight-year-old Nelly meets a strangely familiar girl her own age in the woods. Instantly forming a connection with this mysterious new friend, Nelly embarks on a fantastical journey of discovery which helps her come to terms with this newfound loss.

films.title: Breathless
films.description: A small-time thief steals a car and impulsively murders a motorcycle policeman. Wanted by the authorities, he attempts to persuade a girl to run away to Italy with him.

films.title: Anatomy of a Fall
films.description: A woman is suspected of her husband's murder, and their blind son faces a moral dilemma as the sole witness.

films.title: Au Hasard Balthazar
films.description: The story of a donkey Balthazar as he is passed from owner to owner, some kind and some cruel but all with motivations beyond his understanding. Balthazar, whose life parallels that of his first keeper, Marie, is truly a beast of burden, suffering the sins of humankind. But despite his powerlessness, he accepts his fate nobly.

films.title: Le Trou
films.description: Four prison inmates have been hatching a plan to literally dig out of jail when another prisoner, Claude Gaspard, is moved into their cell. They take a risk and share their plan with the newcomer. Over the course of three days, the prisoners and friends break through the concrete floor using a bed post and begin to make their way through the sewer system -- yet their escape is anything but assured.

timeline.title: Birth of Cinema
timeline.content:
In Paris, on 28 December 1895, Auguste and Louis Lumière held the first-ever public screening of motion pictures at the Salon Indien du Grand Café. Using their invention, the Cinématographe, they projected a series of short films to a paying audience, marking the birth of modern cinema. The Cinématographe was a revolutionary device that combined a camera, printer, and projector in one. Their first screening featured ten short films, including Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory and L'Arroseur Arrosé.

Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory (1895)

L'Arroseur Arrosé (1895)

timeline.title: The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat
timeline.content:
The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896)

On 25 January 1896, in Lyon, the Lumière brothers held the première of arguably the most famous short silent film- The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat. There are accounts that the dynamic perspective of the film, with the train approaching the camera, caused some of the audience to panic and flee the venue, fearing that a real train was about to crash into them. This is, however, likely a myth. There is no evidence supporting the claims, and the grainy picture and lack of sound meant it could never be mistaken for reality.

timeline.title: Alice Guy-Blaché
timeline.content:
Alice Guy-Blaché

Alice Guy-Blaché was a pioneering French filmmaker and one of the first to direct a narrative film. Starting her career at the production company Gaumont in 1896, she directed over 1,000 films, including short comedies, dramas, and early science fiction. She was instrumental in developing the use of synchronized sound in The Cabbage Fairy (1896) and pioneered the use of multi-reel films, which would later become standard in the industry. As the first female filmmaker in history, her work laid the foundation for modern cinema, though her contributions were largely overshadowed for decades.

timeline.title: Georges Méliès
timeline.content:
Georges Méliès

Between 1896 and 1900, Georges Méliès, a former stage magician, revolutionised filmmaking by developing some of the earliest special effects. He discovered stop-motion substitution— where objects or people appeared to vanish or change by stopping the camera, altering the scene, and resuming filming— by accident when his camera jammed. He also pioneered superimposing images, scene transitions and hand-painted color in films like The Haunted Castle (1896) and Cinderella (1899), blending magic and storytelling in ways never seen before.

timeline.title: A Trip to the Moon
timeline.content:
A Trip to the Moon (1902)

A Trip to the Moon is Georges Méliès' most famous film and one of the first science fiction movies. Inspired by Jules Verne, it follows a group of astronomers who build a giant cannon to launch themselves to the Moon, where they encounter fantastical landscapes and hostile Moon creatures. Méliès used groundbreaking special effects, including painted backdrops, jump cuts and superimpositions, to create its dreamlike visuals.

timeline.title: Zoom the White Dolphin
timeline.content:
Zoom the White Dolphin (1971)

The first co-production between France and Japan was the anime series Zoom the White Dolphin. French director René Borg collaborated with Japanese studio Eiken to create the 13-episode series. The series presents Zoom, a white dolphin, and his friends, two children who live with their sailor uncle. Lots of other animals feature, such as a bird who can understand the dolphin language and a koala.

timeline.title: Once Upon a Time... Man
timeline.content:
Once Upon a Time... Man (1978 - 1979)

René Borg later collaborated with Albert Barillé to create the first series in the Once Upon a Time... franchise, which was animated by Tatsunoko Pro. The franchise explains history in a format adapted for children and was well received upon release.

timeline.title: The Inquisitor
timeline.content:
Rashomon (1950)

The Inquisitor (1981)

Japanese director Akira Kurosawa’s Rashomon introduced a groundbreaking narrative technique in which multiple characters recount the same event from conflicting perspectives, leaving the audience to piece together the truth. French film The Inquisitor appears to be influenced by this approach, following a tense police interrogation in which a lawyer, accused of murder, gives conflicting accounts of events. As new revelations emerge, the audience is forced to question the reliability of each account, mirroring how Rashomon challenges the notion of objective truth through its evolving and contradictory narratives.

timeline.title: Ulysses 31
timeline.content:
Ulysses 31 (1981 - 1982)

René Borg and French producer and screenwriter Jean Chalopin went to Japan to work with Tokyo Movie Shinsha on Ulysses 31, an anime series depicting the story of Greek hero Odysseus in a hypothetical 31st century. It was a massive success.
